content: The Act titled "White Sands Fair Compensation Act of 1995" is cited as the short title. The findings section follows. The White Sands Missile Range in New Mexico is crucial for national security. Established during World War II, ranchers and miners were temporarily displaced to contribute to the war effort. In 1975, all land within the Range was permanently taken by the US Government. The US Government has not fully compensated ranchers and miners for land taken within the Range. Compensation methods differ from those used in New Mexico. The Legacy Fellowship Program in Natural and Cultural Resource Management was established. The Department of Defense is sponsoring a 5-year research project on the historical significance of ranching in the area that is now the White Sands Missile Range. The US Government has an obligation to pay full compensation to ranchers and miners for the value of the land and claims taken by the Government. Establishment of Commission. The White Sands Fair Compensation Commission is established in the Department of Defense with nine members appointed by the Secretary of Defense, including representatives from the Department of the Interior and individuals recommended by Senators and Representatives from the State of New Mexico. The White Sands Fair Compensation Commission is established with nine members appointed by the Secretary of Defense, including representatives from the Department of the Interior and individuals recommended by Senators, Representatives, and the Governor of New Mexico. Members are appointed for the life of the Commission, vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment, and members should have expertise in agricultural economics or the history of the White Sands Missile Range. The White Sands Fair Compensation Commission members serve without pay but receive travel expenses. They elect a chairman and other officers as needed, with a quorum of five members required for hearings. The White Sands Fair Compensation Commission members serve without pay but receive travel expenses. They elect a chairman and other officers as needed, with a quorum of five members required for hearings. The Commission may make necessary bylaws, rules, and regulations, and the Secretary provides administrative support. The Commission will terminate 14 months after completing evaluations of claims. Evaluation and payment of claims for compensation related to White Sands Missile Range are governed by Section 4. Claims for compensation for property takings related to the establishment of the White Sands Missile Range in New Mexico are evaluated and paid according to this section. Eligible individuals can submit claims for full compensation for the taking of their property by the United States. Individuals who were engaged in ranching activities on real property taken by the United States to establish the White Sands Missile Range in New Mexico can claim that the compensation paid in 1975 was not full. Additionally, individuals who possessed a mining claim on the taken property can also claim inadequate compensation. Individuals who were engaged in ranching activities on real property taken by the United States for the White Sands Missile Range in New Mexico can claim inadequate compensation paid in 1975. The heirs or assigns of these individuals can also submit claims. Claims must be submitted within 14 months of the enactment of the Act, and the Commission will evaluate each claim to determine eligibility. The Commission will determine if the compensation paid by the United States in 1975 for real property or mining claims was full. If not, they will calculate the full compensation amount and notify the individual and the Secretary of Defense. The Commission will use established precedents to value real property. The Commission will prioritize evaluating claims from individuals who owned real property continuously from 1941 to 1975. They will use established precedents for property valuation and consider the value added by Federal grazing permits. Lease payments by the US Government between 1942 and 1975 will not be factored in. Individuals who owned real property continuously from 1941 to 1975 can appeal a determination of the Commission by submitting a notice of appeal to the Secretary of Defense within 30 days. The Secretary will review each appeal within 60 days and provide relief accordingly. The Secretary will review appeals of property or mining claim disputes, upholding the Commission's decision or providing full compensation. The compensation set by the Secretary cannot be less than the Commission's determination. Individuals appealing will be notified of the Secretary's decision. The Secretary's decision under paragraph (3) is final and not subject to judicial review. The Secretary of Defense will pay the individual the upheld or established compensation amount, subject to the availability of appropriated funds. SEC. 5. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. Authorization for activities of the White Sands Fair Compensation Commission under this Act and payment of claims are authorized to be appropriated such sums as necessary, with $20,300,000 allocated for claims under section 4.
